While I appreciate the effort of this writer to talk about this issue, I have to point out that he presents only one side of the story. He makes an Ender Wiggins like apology as a "speaker for the dead". But he fails to appreciate the advantages that the living - both humans and animals - have gained from such research... and are very thankful for.

The reality is that much of what we know about our own physiology and about effective treatment for many diseases and conditions comes from animal research. For those who think animal research should cease today, try and go without your allergy or asthma medication or pain relievers for a year and then decide if giving up this kind of research is what you really want.

While there are certainly cases of failed oversight, the author fails to mention that such research is extremely tightly regulated. Faculty, graduate students and postdoctoral trainees have to abide by strict regulations to maintain the privilege of being able to do such research... or risk losing not just this privilege, but their jobs.

A major goal of biomedical and bio-behavioral research is to minimize and eventually eliminate the dependence on animals for research. But until we have sufficiently advanced simulation machines for the entire body, we need to do what we can to ensure the good health and survival of ALL animals, including ourselves... and that means well-regulated animal research.

No Pascal's triangle is required for the second problem.  It is clearer if one changes the problem ever so slightly.  Except for the arrival of the very last passenger, when a passenger arrives to find neir seat already taken suppose it is instead the person who was already sitting in that seat who is the one who chooses a random unoccupied seat.  This change to the problem does not change which seats get claimed.  However, with this change to the problem, it will always be the very first passenger who is choosing a random unoccupied seat.  Now, the 50/50 solution is more apparent.

I think this works. With your labeling scheme, just before the last passenger boards, everyone will be in their assigned seats except perhaps the first passenger. This poor fellow might have luckily started in his own seat to begin with, but more likely will have been bumped out of many seats, since he doesn't know which is his true assigned seat. As the plane fills he is bumped out of more and more seats. So finally, it is 50/50 he has landed in the last passenger's seat, but why?  On each bump, he gets higher and higher chances of landing in one of these two seats, his own or the last passenger's. Since all seats are equal to him, the likelihood of his landing in his own or the last passengers seat are equal.

Favorites:

1) The guard tells 100 prisoners that they will be executed in the morning. But, he says, there is a chance to live. He will line them up wearing black or white hats such that each sees only the hats of the prisoners ahead in the line. They will start with the last man (who sees 99 hats) and guess the hat on their own head, white or black, and make no signals. If correct, that prisoner will live. That night the men make a strategy to save the most lives. What is it?

2) 100 passengers are boarding a plane that has 100 seats. The first man looses his seat assignment and sits in a random seat. After that, the passengers enter, one-by-one, and sit in their assigned seat if it still available, or else sit in a random empty seat. What is the probability the 100th man will get his assigned seat?

3) There are 3 switches in a room. Each controls one of three light bulbs in a second room, which is out of sight of the first. The switch positions are "on" or "off". You operate the switches and then you enter the second room. How do you determine which switch controls which bulb?

As K notes, child support is already decriminalized. That's why so many fathers are in prison. If not paying the ordered amount of child support were a criminal matter, the accused father would be entitled to (1) a government-provided attorney, and (2) a presumption of innocence (which might include poking into the reason that the child support amount ordered exceeded the father's actual income). The current system works smoothly because the deadbeat dad (or occasionally mom) is the only person in the courtroom who is not an expert/attorney. So it is into the courtroom for a 3-minute hearing and then off to prison for a while.

The testing company makes a lot of money. Pearson is the largest corporation serving this testing market. Pearson is the world’s largest education company and book publisher, bringing in more than $9 billion annually.

Currently, Pearson has partnered with 18 states in the U.S., as well as Washington, D.C. and Puerto Rico, to produce pricey testing materials. For a five-year contract, Pearson was paid $32 million to produce standardized tests for New York. Its contract in Texas was worth $500 million. Pearson also owns Connections Academy, a company that runs for-profit, virtual charter schools. It also owns the GED program, although competitors have been creating alternatives in order to combat Pearson’s expensive tests. By and large, the massive corporation has far-reaching control over the education industry.

In Texas a Pearson employee was on the ballot for a School Board election, and lost.

Demographically, it's college educated middle class parents who are doing most of the opting out, and they don't work for the union, nor does the  the union tell them what to think. The Iowa Basic skills tests was developed by the University of Iowa, a public university. Back in the day, when I took this test there was no test prep involved. There was feedback, useful feedback. I was surprised to find out, they still have this test although the name has changed. Perhaps the standardized tests used in public schools should be those that have been developed by PUBLIC universities, instead of PRIVATE entities that need to reinvent the wheel to make the all mighty profit. We also need to stop with the high-stakes aspect of testing.

PARENTS are leading the fight against the current NY state tests and the way they're being used. The Pearson tests, given to 8-13 y.o. students over 6 days and 7 hours, result in a score between 1 and 4, given to teachers after the school year ends. There's no granularity/utility to the data. The tests do what they're meant to-- close schools & fire teachers so Cuomo can look like a reformer.

NY teachers now have 50% of their evaluation turn on "Value Added Measures"-- roughly how much their students improve year over year. The American Statistical Association says teachers are responsible for 1-14% of a student's test performance, yet those teachers whose students don't improve, even by a tiny margin, cannot be rated above "developing." English Language Learners and kids with IEPs take the tests too. Art, Science, and Music teachers are (somehow) also rated by these VAMs. Passing scores are determined after results are in. Teachers and administrators risk censure for even VIEWING the tests, let alone criticizing them.

The practical effects of this arbitrary system of evaluation are what's driving PARENT dissatisfaction: a narrowing of the curriculum felt most acutely at low-performing schools & the demoralizing effect of that loss of creativity and autonomy on students and teachers. 12 years of NCLB tests and the "achievement gap" hasn't closed-- will these do the trick? We are destroying public education and scaring away teachers; this parent considers that an emergency.
